author: Written by: FOX8Live.com Staff
title: New Orleans residents reminded about free smoke detector program
text:
NEW ORLEANS, LA (WVUE) - As part of Fire Prevention Week, the New Orleans Fire Department has joined forces with the non-profit National Fire Protection Association, the Louisiana State Fire Marshal and The American Red Cross to remind local residents to "Hear the Beep, Where You Sleep."
During this year's fire safety campaign, the NOFD is spreading the word about the importance of working smoke detectors throughout the home, but most importantly in the bedroom — and teaching local residents how to test smoke detectors monthly and replace non-working or outdated smoke detectors.
So far this year, the New Orleans Fire Department has installed almost 5,600 smoke alarms and batteries in the homes of Orleans Parish residents.
The Louisiana State Fire Marshal's Office and the American Red Cross have been instrumental, donating over 6800 10-year lithium battery smoke alarms to support this effort.
According to the latest research from the Fire Protection Association, working smoke alarms cut the chance of dying in a fire in half. Meanwhile, almost two-thirds of home fire deaths resulted from fires in homes with no smoke alarms or no working smoke alarms.
This year's Fire Prevention Week campaign includes the following smoke alarm messages:
• Install smoke alarms in every bedroom, outside each separate sleeping area and on every level of the home, including the basement.
• Interconnect all smoke alarms throughout the home. This way, when one sounds, they all do.
• Test alarms at least monthly by pushing the test button.
• Replace all smoke alarms when they are 10 years old or sooner if they don't respond properly.
• Make sure everyone in the home knows the sound of the smoke alarm and understands what to do when they hear it.
For years now the New Orleans Fire Department has been conducting its "Save Lives, Install Dat" Smoke Detector Installation Program.
Fire department officials say uniformed, on-duty NOFD personnel will visit homes, churches and non-profit organizations to assess fire safety needs and install 10-year Lithium Battery Smoke Detectors or replace 9-volt batteries in hard-wired smoke detector systems for any Orleans Parish Resident in need.
New Orleans Fire Department Superintendent Tim McConnell often states that during his "entire career in the fire service, I have never experienced a fire related fatality where a working smoke detector was present."
McConnell encourages residents to learn more about the department's Community Outreach and Fire Safety Programs and activities.
To request a smoke detector through the "Save Lives, Install Dat" Smoke Detector Program, " call 504-658-4714 or visit nola.gov/nofd
